DOCNAME: CASE OF EVA MOLNÁR v. HUNGARY
TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicant was born in DATE and lives in GPE , GPE .
CARDINAL . The facts of the case , as submitted by the parties , may be summarised as follows .

CARDINAL . On DATE ( first round ) and CARDINAL ( second round ) DATE legislative elections took place in GPE . The coalition which had governed the country from DATE and , therefore , had been in charge of organising the elections , lost their majority .

CARDINAL . The official results of the elections were established by the local and regional electoral commissions following the second round . After the courts had ruled on certain complaints concerning the legality and outcome of the voting procedure , on DATE ORG made a public statement in ORG , according to which the result had become final . As in previous NORP elections , they were virtually identical to the results of the exit poll carried out on DATE of the second round and to the preliminary results announced by ORG DATE . Nevertheless , views were subsequently voiced in certain sections of the media that the elections had been “ rigged ” .

CARDINAL . International observers , in particular ORG in LOC ( OSCE ) , found that the parliamentary elections had been conducted in a manner consistent with international standards and that the NORP election system had provided the basis for a generally transparent , accountable , free , fair and equal process .

CARDINAL . A period of DATE elapsed during which a new government , in a coalition of the ex - opposition parties , was formed which took up its functions on CARDINAL DATE . On TIME , DATE CARDINAL demonstrators started to protest against the statutory destruction of the ballots , scheduled for DATE . They blocked the centrally located FAC in GPE with their cars . Their objective was to force a recount of the election votes . Since they brought the traffic to a complete standstill and had not given prior notice of their gathering to the police , as required by Act no . DATE on ORG ( “ the LAW ” ) , the demonstration was dispersed after TIME .

CARDINAL . Shortly afterwards , at TIME , more demonstrators , again without any prior notification , assembled at FAC in front of the ORG building demanding a recount of the votes and expressing their support for the participants in the TIME ’s events at FAC .

CARDINAL . According to the applicant ’s submissions of DATE and the ORG ’s observations , these demonstrators had been at FAC and then relocated to FAC . However , in her submissions of DATE , the applicant stated that they had merely been supporters of those who had blocked FAC .

CARDINAL . Having learnt of these events from the news , the applicant joined the demonstration at TIME By that time , traffic and public transport – including the circulation of trams and trolley - buses – had become seriously disrupted in the area of FAC . The estimated number of demonstrators ranged from CARDINAL . The police initially attempted to allow the circulation of traffic to continue but eventually had to close some streets nearby . Finally , faced with an unmanageable situation , they broke up the demonstration at TIME without using any force . The applicant participated in the demonstration until it was dispersed .

CARDINAL . NORP The NORP media reported in detail on the events , and the affair was the leading news in the country . In an official communiqué , the President of the GPE condemned the events of DATE , declaring them illegal . He underlined that GPE was a stable parliamentary democracy where human rights were observed and where even critical views should be voiced in a lawful manner .
CARDINAL . The applicant sought judicial review of the actions of the police before ORG . She asserted that the dispersal of the demonstration had been unlawful .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG dismissed the applicant ’s claim . It established that the duty to inform the police about planned assemblies was applicable to every type of demonstration , including spontaneous ones . Since the applicant did not deny that the demonstration in question had not been notified to the police , as required by section CARDINAL of LAW , the latter had not had any other choice but to break it up .

CARDINAL . NORP Moreover , the court found that the duty to inform the police in advance about assemblies held in public served the protection of the public interest and the rights of others , namely the prevention of disorder and the undisturbed circulation of traffic . Therefore , it concluded that the measures taken by the police had been in compliance with the law .
CARDINAL . The applicant appealed . On DATE ORG upheld the first - instance decision . Its judgment was served on the applicant ’s lawyer on DATE .
CARDINAL . The LAW of GPE no . DATE as amended ) provides , in so far as relevant , as follows :
“ GPE acknowledges the right to peaceful assembly and secures its free exercise . ”
CARDINAL . The relevant provisions of Act no . DATE on ORG ( “ the LAW ” ) read as follows :

“ ( CARDINAL ) The exercise of freedom of assembly shall not constitute a crime or an incitement to crime ; moreover , it should not result in the infringement of the rights and freedoms of others . ”

“ The organisation of an event held in the public domain shall be notified to the competent police headquarters according to the place of the event , and in GPE to ORG , DATE prior to the planned date of the event . The obligation to notify the police lies with the organiser of the event . ”

“ ( CARDINAL ) If the holding of an event subject to prior notification seriously endangers the proper functioning of the representative bodies or courts , or results in a disproportionate hindrance of the circulation of traffic , the police may ban the holding of the event at the place or time indicated in the notification , within TIME from the receipt of the notification by the authority . ”
“ ( CARDINAL ) No appeal shall lie against the decision of the police , but the organiser may seek judicial review of the administrative decision within DATE of its notification . ”

“ ( CARDINAL ) The police shall disperse the event if the exercise of the right to freedom of assembly contravenes subparagraph CARDINAL of section CARDINAL or if the participants appear at the event ... in possession of arms , or if an event subject to prior notification is held without notification , ... or despite a decision banning the event . ...
( CARDINAL ) If an event is dispersed , the participants may seek judicial review within DATE with a view to the establishment of the illegality of the dispersal . ”
